src:
Abogado de Uribe vuelve al país para responder por supuesta manipulación de testigos
Se trata de Diego Cadena, quien deberá presentarse a interrogatorio ante la Fiscalía General de la Nación este martes 5 de noviembre a las 9:00 de la mañana.

04 Nov 2019, 16:33

Cadena presentaría pruebas nuevas para demostrar su inocencia ante los señalmientos de sobornar al exparamilitar preso Carlos Enrique Vélez para que este cambiara su testimonio en un caso que vincula al senador Álvaro Uribe Vélez, indicó RCN Radio.
El medio añadió que el abogado tiene pensado justificar que el dinero que le dio al testigo era parte de una ayuda humanitaria y que para esto divulgará conversaciones telefónicas y documentos en los que constaría que Vélez, conocido con el alias de ‘Víctor’, le pedía dinero por motivos personales.
Por su parte, el periódico El Tiempo agregó que Diego Cadena también deberá aclarar el motivo por el que escribió a mano cartas firmadas por al menos 2 testigos del caso.
Uribe, entre tanto, ha dicho en reiteradas oportunidades que no sabía de los pagos de su abogado a alias ‘Víctor’ y que de haberse enterado, se lo hubiera impedido, pues su caso es por presunto soborno a testigos y fraude procesal.
text:
Uribe lawyer returns to the country to answer for alleged witness manipulation
This is Diego Cadena, who must appear for questioning before the Attorney General's Office this Tuesday, November 5 at 9:00 in the morning.

04 Nov 2019, 16:33

Cadena would present new evidence to prove his innocence at the signs of bribing the former prisoner Carlos Enrique Vélez to change his testimony in a case that links Senator Álvaro Uribe Vélez, RCN Radio said.
The media added that the lawyer plans to justify that the money he gave to the witness was part of a humanitarian aid and that for this he will disseminate telephone conversations and documents in which it would be stated that Vélez, known with the alias of 'Victor', asked Money for personal reasons.
For its part, the newspaper El Tiempo added that Diego Cadena should also clarify the reason why he handwritten letters signed by at least 2 witnesses in the case.
Uribe, meanwhile, has repeatedly said that he did not know about his lawyer's payments to alias ‘Víctor’ and that if he had learned, he would have prevented it, since his case is for alleged bribery of witnesses and procedural fraud.
